Halifax lift Cup after thrilling final

20/06/2013

A sensational College Cup final saw Halifax firsts crowned champions, after beating Derwent firsts 3-2

Image by

By undefined undefined

HALIFAX FIRSTS 3-2 DERWENT FIRSTS College Cup Final [flickr-slideshow tags="derwent1shalifax1s210613"] Images: Agatha Torrance A sensational College Cup final saw Halifax firsts crowned champions, after beating Derwent firsts 3-2 this afternoon. In what was the best match of the entire tournament, Halifax came from behind twice to ultimately take victory. Dan Atherton scored twice for Derwent to put them in control of the game, but goals from Ash Daly, Matt Darling, and Connor Meckin tipped things in Halifax's favour. Halifax made one change from the side that beat Halifax seconds in the semis, Guy Bowden coming in at right back ahead of Kieran Gennoy. Alex D'Albertanson was the surprise selection at right back for Derwent, who again started Jamie Trant on the subs bench. It was Derwent who took control early on and they maintained that for much of the first half. Atherton curled an early free kick just over the bar, with too little room to get it beyond the wall and back down into the top corner, before captain Ollie Harrison headed over the bar from a corner. It was a highly-charged opening, both sides clearly up for the fight, as Matt Mawdesley proved with a crunching challenge on Mirhire Overo-Tarimo. All the play was in the Halifax half, though, and their centre half pairing of Alex Tringham and Matt Seed had to stay strong to hold back the early onslaught of set pieces. They were taken apart soon, however, as a lovely exchange of passes on the edge of the area between Atherton and Joe Easter saw the former played through on goal, but he dragged a shot past the post. Halifax were struggling to hold the ball up, failing to put Derwent under any sustained pressure with the men in blue dominating the midfield. And 10 minutes before the break, Derwent took a deserved lead. Easter pounced on a loose ball and fed Atherton to slide a finish past Jonny Sim. It was a soft goal for Fax to concede, but it was no less than Derwent's positive start had merited. There was a very brief resurgence from Fax, but they still never troubled Frank Woodcock in the Derwent net, as Tom Brandreth and Dave Belshaw looked predictably solid. The first half ended at 1-0, with Derwent looking far livelier and Fax knowing they would need to raise their game to take the trophy home. And they did come out fighting. Within minutes of referee Dan Horsfall restarting play, Tringham got on the end of a long throw from Hamish Denham, such a potent weapon in the knockout stages so far, but hit the bar from only a couple of yards out. The mood among the hoards of Derwent supporters was still far more jovial than in the Fax camp, but that was about to change. Ash Daly stood over a free kick 25 yards out and curled a low effort around the wall which evaded everyone and crept into the bottom corner to level the scores. It was a goal that Halifax desperately needed to restore some confidence to their play. However, Derwent were ahead again within five minutes. The same combination proved pivotal again, Easter bursting through the middle to set up Atherton. The frontman produced yet another composed finish to beat Sim, who had not conceded a goal until this Monday, and wheeled away in shirt-less celebration. Halifax's hard work to get level had been undone, but the game was about to turn on a controversial decision. With the players lining up for a Halifax corner, a push on Alex Tringham was spotted by Horsfall, who signalled for a penalty. After a lengthy delay and protests from the Derwent players, it was Halifax captain Darling who stepped up to take it. Darling, who later remarked that he "wasn't nervous at all" about taking the spot kick, kept his cool to send Woodcock the wrong way and make it 2-2. If that was bad for Derwent, things were about to get much worse. Seconds later, a seemingly harmless ball floated over their defence brought Woodcock out to clear, only for Brandreth to head the ball back away from him and towards goal. Substitute Meckin ran onto it and slid home from a tight angle into the empty net, handing Halifax the advantage for the first time. The tension had been ramped up to another level, as this already enthralling match left the huge crowd stunned. Every decision was furiously contested by both sets of players and fans, as Derwent mounted a late charge for an equaliser. Brandreth bombarded the Halifax penalty area with long throw after long throw, one finding the head of Overo-Tarimo, who couldn't nudge it goalwards. Darling, who took himself off the pitch for Dave Lewis, was stood saying to himself "please see this out, please see this out", as Derwent refused to go down without a fight. A late corner, with Woodcock up to challenge for it, almost paid dividends for Derwent, but the Fax defence would not be breached again. The full-time whistle went, with Halifax celebrating wildly and Derwent's players on their knees. There were handshakes all round, recognising the quality of a superb hour of football befitting of a cup final. An elated Darling told Nouse afterwards, "That's the best feeling I can possibly describe, I really think we deserved it. But first mention has to go to Derwent they were fantastic as well. We went out and did what we had to do, and it was great to come away with the Cup." Derwent's Harrison added, "We're obviously very disappointed, but they put their chances away today. We made a few mistakes and that cost us today, we weren't clinical enough. I just want to say that the team have done fantastically well, we're a solid outfit and the best team. But today, we weren't quite good enough to see off a very rugged Halifax team." For the second time in three years, Halifax had emerged victorious in the final, banishing the ghosts of last year's shootout defeat to Vanbrugh. And, much to the delight of all present, the most thrilling chapter of College Cup 2013 had most certainly been saved for last. Halifax: Sim, Bowden, Seed, Tringham, Darling (Lewis), Jones, Daly, Mawdesley, McCoy (Gennoy), Day, Denham (Meckin). Man of the match: Alex Tringham Derwent: Woodcock, D'Albertanson, Belshaw, Brandreth, Harrison, Gwinnett, Earle, Overo-Tarimo, Atherton, Easter, Kirk (Trant). Man of the match: Dan Atherton
